title: What's a good book about waves and how they're formed? - Quora

response.answer_text: If you mean in the ocean, any introductory college textbook on oceanography, preferably he heavy-duty kind for students who are actully majoring in oceanography. As I recalled it's starts with wind causing tiny waves. These then overlap and join together because of surface tension. This gives them a larger surface for the wind to effect them more. Plus of course gravity drives them forward. When the water depth reaches 1/2 wavelength the waves touch bottom, get higher, and eventually curl because the bottom of the wave is slowing down while the top continues with its previous momentum.
For us Ocean Engineers, Dean and Dalrymple's "Water Wave Mechanics for Engineers and Scientists"  is the classic.
